questions.text: A four month old infant presented with a cloudy cornea. On exam, you discover that corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle. Which of the following statements is correct about the incisional angle surgery preferred for this case?

options.label: A
options.text: IOP must be lowered and miotics should be administered before commencing the surgical treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Brimonidine is preferred due to rapid onset of action

options.label: C
options.text: Barkan’s knife is primarily used in the surgery

options.label: D
options.text: The main difficulty in this operation is localization of the Schlemm’s canal

questions.correct_answer: D. The main difficulty in this operation is localization of the Schlemm’s canal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The main difficulty in this operation is localization of the Schlemm’s canal Incisional angle surgery , which can be performed by the internal approach ( goniotomy ) or by external approach ( trabeculectomy ). Trabeculotomy is useful when corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle or in cases where goniotomy has failed. Harm’s trabeculotome is used in this procedure. The main difficulty in this operation is the localization of Schlemm’s canal .

Highyeild:

Post - Operative Complications : Shallow Anterior chamber pupillary block malignant glaucoma bleb leakage bacterial infection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Medications are not very effective, so the treatment of congenital glaucoma is primarily surgical. However, IOP must be lowered by medical treatment with hyperosmotic agents, acetazolamide, and beta blockers until surgery is taken up. Miotics are not used in such cases because they paradoxically increase IOP . Option: B. Alpha - 2 agonists ( brimonidine ) cause CNS depression in children and are contraindicated. Option: C. Barkan’s goniotomy knife is used in internal approach surgery. or goniotomy.

Extraedge:

Cyclo destructive procedures Surgical and laser procedures that ablate the ciliary body to the lower the IOP. Surgery: cyclocryotherapy Laser - cryophotocoagulation

questions.text: A three month old infant is referred to the ophthalmology department due to suspicion of having congenital glaucoma. The examination for this infant should include which of the following? Perkin’s applanation tonometer Slit-lamp examination with rigid in built slit-lamp machine Gonioscopic examination of angle of posterior chamber Measurement of corneal diameter Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 and 4 A complete examination under general anaesthesia (EUA) should be performed on each child suspected of having congenital glaucoma. The examination should includes following: measurement of IOP Measurement of corneal diameter Slit-lamp examination Ophthalmoscopy Gonioscopic examination Types of congenital glaucoma : Primary Developmental / Congenital glaucoma Developmental Glaucoma with associated specific ocular or systemic congenital anomalies. Gonioscopic examination of the angle of the anterior chamber reveals trabeculodysgenesis with either flat or concave iris insertion, as described in the pathogenesis of glaucoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Measurement of IOP should be done with a Schiotz or preferably handheld Perkin’s applanation tonometer since scleral rigidity is very low in children. The IOP measurement under GA is unpredictably altered. Option: B . A slit-lamp examination should be carried out with a portable slit-lamp. Option: D. Measurement of corneal diameter by calipers for a complete ophthalmologic exam of an infant with suspected glaucoma.

Extraedge:

Most cases are sporadic . About 10% of cases exhibit autosomal recessive inheritance with incomplete penetrance. The genes implicated are GLC3A, GLC3B, and GLC3C.

questions.text: A twwo month old infant presents with bilateral cloudy cornea, lacrimation and raised IOP. Which of the following statements are true regarding this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Concave iris insertion is more common in such cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Due to corneal clouding, it is never possible to visualize a portion of the ciliary body and scleral spur.

options.label: C
options.text: Tears in Descemet’s membrane are usually peripheral and appear as lines with a double contour.

options.label: D
options.text: A bilateral occurrence is seen in 30% of cases.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tears in Descemet’s membrane are usually peripheral and appear as lines with a double contour.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tears in Descemet’s membrane are usually peripheral and appear as lines with a double contour. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of congenital glaucoma . Maldevelopment, from neural crest- derived cells, of trabeculum, including the iridotrabecular junction (trabeculodysgenesis), is responsible for impaired aqueous outflow, resulting in raised IOP . Tears and breaks in Descemet’s membrane ( Haab’s striae ) occur because Descemet’s membrane is less elastic than the corneal stroma. Tears are usually peripheral , concentric with the limbus and appear as lines with a double contour .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Flat iris insertion is more common than concave iris insertion. In it, the iris inserts flatly and abruptly into the thickened trabeculum, either at or anterior to scleral spur (more often) or posterior to scleral spur. It is often possible to visualize a portion of the ciliary body and scleral spur . Option: B. It is often possible to visualize a portion of the ciliary body and scleral spur in flat iris insertion; which is seen more commonly. Concave iris insertion is less common. In it the superficial iris tissue sweeps over the iridotrabecular junction and the trabeculum and, thus, obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body. Since concave iris insertion occurs in the majority of the cases, we can rule this option out as a statement of complete fact. Option: D. The bilateral occurrence is seen in 70% of cases, though the involvement may be asymmetric.

Extraedge:

In primary congenital glaucoma, the trabeculodysgenesis is not associated with any other major ocular anomalies.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child has been brought in due to watering and photophobia for the past few months. They also report the presence of nn asymmetrically large left eye. On exam, you notice the presence of corneal haze, corneal scarring, and optic disc cupping. The exam findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's condition is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery is always required and is successful in 80–90%

options.label: B
options.text: Trabeculotomy may be necessary if repeated goniotomy has failed

options.label: C
options.text: Amblyopia and refractive error should be actively managed only after it does not improve after the correction

options.label: D
options.text: Tube shunt implantation may be necessary if repeated goniotomy has failed

questions.correct_answer: C. Amblyopia and refractive error should be actively managed only after it does not improve after the correction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amblyopia and refractive error should be actively managed only after it does not improve after the correction The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of buphthalmos . The first image shows corneal haze , while the second image shows unilateral buphthalmos in the left eye. Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years . The thinned sclera often appears blue due to increased visualization of the underlying uvea. Complications include myopia and lens subluxation. Amblyopia and refractive error should be managed aggressively instead of waiting for the correction of glaucoma. This is to prevent further complications.

Highyeild:

Buphthalmos appears between birth and 4 years of age. Both eyes are usually involved, but to varying degrees of severity. Boys are more affected than girls.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Surgery is always required and is successful in 80–90%. Medication may be used as temporary or supplementary therapy. Caution is required with selection of medication in young children, as most are relatively contraindicated. Option: B. Trabeculotomy may be necessary if corneal clouding prevents an adequate view of the angle and is also an option when repeated goniotomy has failed. A partial-thickness scleral flap is created and a Harms trabeculotome is inserted into the Schlemm canal and rotated into the anterior chamber. Option: D. Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation and ciliary body ablative procedures.

Extraedge:

Diagnosis Measurement of IOP with a Schiotz or hand held Perkin’s applanation tonometer . measurement of corneal diameter by callipers. gonioscopic examination of anterior chamber angle.

questions.text: Hypersecretory glaucoma is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidemic Dropsy The diagnosis of epidemic dropsy glaucoma is made after an outbreak of pedal edema in many areas of a community of many members of a household in an endemic area . A history of coloured haloes in young individuals, normal anterior chamber depth, a raised intraocular pressure and retinal vascular changes are highly suggestive. Confirmation by the presence of sanguinarine in oil , blood, and urine is diagnostic. The disease has a self-limiting course but if left untreated, leads to optic disk cupping and optic atrophy. The possibility of epidemic dropsy glaucoma should be kept in mind when considering individuals from endemic areas, a past history of beri-beri. edema, signs of advanced disc and field changes but normal intraocular pressure.

Highyeild:

The main symptom of epidemic dropsy consists of bilateral pitting edema of legs, often associated with erythema, diarrhoea, dyspnoea , glaucoma along with cardiac and respiratory problems in severe cases, leading to death.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Marfan's syndrome - Marfan syndrome affects the heart, eyes, blood vessels and bones. People with Marfan syndrome are tall, and thin with long arms, legs, fingers and toes. Treatment includes medication to keep blood pressure low, glasses or contact lenses and surgery. Option: C . Hypertension - It is not associated with hypersecretory glaucoma. Option: D . Diabetes - Not associated with hypersecretory glaucoma .

Extraedge:

Treatment Withdrawal of contaminated oil bed rest with leg elevation and a protein rich diet Supplements of calcium, antioxidants, and thiamine vitamin.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with markedly cloudy cornea, and elevated IOP. His parents reported that this condition has been present since birth. Which surgical procedure would be initially used to manage primary congenital glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trabeculotomy Management of congenital glaucoma involves surgery, either goniotomy (70% success) or trabeculotomy (70% to 80% success). Surgery is the mainstay of treatment for congenital glaucoma. A goniotomy is performed for a clear cornea Trabeculectomy for a hazy cornea . Trabeculectomy and shunt procedures only when goniotomy or trabeculectomy fails.

Highyeild:

Most cases are sporadic. About 10% of cases exhibit an autosomal recessive inheritance with incomplete penetrance. Genes implicated are GLC3A, GLC3B, and GLC3C .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In general, for primary congenital glaucoma , if repeated attempts at goniotomy and/or trabeculotomy fail, filtering surgery with mitomycin C or seton placement is considered. Topical medication, such as β-blockers, miotics, or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can temporize and potentially clear the cornea enough to allow goniotomy to be performed. Option: B. Cyclophotocoagulation and other cyclodestructive procedures usually are reserved for eyes that have undergone other unsuccessful surgeries. Option: C. A goniotomy requires that the cornea be clear enough to view the meshwork. In the scenario presented, a trabeculotomy Ab externo is the procedure of choice because of the cloudy cornea.

questions.text: A neonate, 30 days old, presented with excessive lacrimation and photophobia, he has a large and hazy cornea. His two lacrimal duct systems are normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital glaucoma Clinical features of congenital cataract Tears and breaks in Descemet’s membrane (Haab’s striae) Corneal signs . Corneal signs include oedema, enlargement, and Descemet’s breaks . Corneal oedema. It is the first sign. Corneal enlargement . It occurs along with the enlargement of globe-buphthalmos it usually seen in children less than 3 yearsof age. Normal infant cornea measures 10.5 mm. A diameter of more than 13 mm confirms enlargement. Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm often form the classic triad of symptoms of congenital glaucoma. The sclera becomes thin and appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. The anterior chamber becomes deep . Iris may show iridodonesis and atrophic patches in the late stage. The lens becomes flat due to stretching of zonules and may even subluxate backward. Optic disc may show variable cupping and atrophy IOP is raised, but not acutely Axial myopia may occur because of increase in axial length which may give rise to anisometropic

Slit-lamp examination should be carried out with portable slit-lamp. Ophthalmoscopy to evaluate optic disc. Gonioscopic examination of angle of anterior chamber reveals with either flat or concave Rx - Drugs like CA inhibitors and beta blockers Surgical management Trabeculotomy + trabeculectomy is TOC Trabeculotomy is the 2nd TOC Goniotomy- is TOC for clear cornea

Megalocornea - Megalocornea (MGC1) is a rare developmental defect characterized by nonprogressive, usually symmetric, bilateral enlargement of the diameter of the cornea (≥13 mm). With keratoconus, the clear, dome-shaped tissue that covers the eye (cornea) thins and bulges outward into a cone shape. Its cause is unknown. Hunter’s syndromes - Hunter syndrome is a very rare , inherited genetic disorder caused by a missing or malfunctioning enzyme. In Hunter syndrome, the body doesn't have enough of the enzyme iduronate 2-sulfatase .
